body.section: The marketing department wants to record all contacts ( telephone, mail, email, visits) in order to calculate the costs incurred for a customer. For each contact, the contact type, date, start time and end time, subject and any charges (e.g. to send a gift ) are tracked. If for example an employee has spend half an hour with a letter, then it must be possible to calculate later that the costs are 0.5 * $60.To do this, create a new table named Contacts and link this to table Customers and enforce referential integrity.

Solution
Normally you should first do â€‹an information analysis. The result should be which fields are necessary in table Contacts, what will be the key and which relationships through which fields. Therefore multiple solutions are possible. One solution could be as displayed in the next figure:
Considerations for this design and other designs:
Several contacts of a customer should be recorded. Hence a key field ContactID and the field CustomerCode (data type: Number - Long Integer) providing a link with table Customers.
If table Employees is available, then it is so convenient to be able to register which employee has handled the contact. In that case add fieldEmployeeCode (data type: Number - Long Integer) providing a link with table Employees.
Information analysis should give you the values for field ContactType. For this field you should create list box with these values.
For the three date / time fields a suitable format should be selected, possibly with an input mask.
Information analysis should tell you how the costs are calculated. The processing time can be calculated from the start and end times, so it is process data and should therefore not be included in the table. If the hourly rate is a constant, then it can also be omitted from the table. In that case, there is nothing about the costs included in the table and the cost are calculated in a query or report. Varies the hourly rate or time, then the hourly rate should be included in the table.
